ContentStructure.title: Healthy Eating for Pregnant Women Living With HIV

This project is based on the report “A Review of Nutritional Recommendations for Pregnant Women Living with HIV”, prepared by the Saskatchewan Prevention Institute. Please refer to this report for more detailed information.
Healthy Eating for Pregnant Women Living With HIV

Vertical (mother-to-child) transmission of HIV is the primary way that children become infected with HIV, and transmission may be indirectly related to the mother’s nutritional status.    A healthy nutritional status may lower the chance of HIV transmission to the baby by improving immune function in the mother and baby, reducing the mother’s viral load, and reducing the risks of low birth weight and prematurity.   The following presentation provides information on: healthy nutrition for pregnant women living with HIV safe food handling and eating practices during pregnancy the importance of healthy weight gain during pregnancy  helpful links for additional information
Healthy Eating for Pregnant Women Living With HIV
Click on a button below to begin.

Proper nutrition is important for all women to be healthy during pregnancy and for their babies to grow and develop.    A healthy immune system is particularly important for women living with HIV in order to keep their immune systems strong and able to fight off infections. Healthy eating can strengthen the immune system. Eating well can also help the body cope with side effects of HIV medicine.   A pregnant woman living with HIV who is getting all the nutrients she needs is helping to protect her baby from getting HIV.
It is important for all pregnant women to eat a balanced diet that includes carbohydrates, protein, and healthy fats.

Although there are no specific recommended daily amounts for pregnant women living with HIV, it is important that they keep their immune systems strong in order to have healthy pregnancies and to avoid transmitting HIV to their babies.
Healthy Eating  Click on the buttons below to find out more about healthy eating.

It is important for a pregnant woman to be aware of how much fat she is eating. There are harmful fats, such as saturated fat or trans-fat. These fats can increase the risk of heart disease and can be harmful to the body. Healthy fats, such as monounsaturated fats and omega-3 fatty acids, provide energy and help the body grow and develop. Healthy fats are available in fish, nuts, avocados, and oils such as olive oil, canola oil, flax oil, and nut oils. It is important to learn to identify fats by reading labels of processed foods.

Protein is used by every part of the body, and it helps to strengthen the immune system. Pregnant women living with HIV need protein to keep their immune systems strong. People do not need large amounts of protein to meet their nutritional needs. Choosing protein from plants more often is recommended. Some examples of foods that are high in protein include beans, nuts, tofu, fish and shellfish, meat, eggs, milk, and cheese.

Eating carbohydrates produces energy. A pregnant woman living with HIV needs carbohydrates to stay healthy and help her baby grow. Healthy carbohydrates include whole grain breads and cereals, and fruits and vegetables. It is best if carbohydrates are eaten at every meal.
Although there are no special recommended daily amounts specific to pregnant women living with HIV, there are some vitamins and minerals that are very important for all pregnant women.
Vitamins and Minerals Click on the buttons below for more information.

Folic acid is the synthetic form of folate.   Folate is one of the B vitamins and is found naturally in citrus fruits, raw leafy green vegetables, beans, peas, lentils, and liver. The levels of folate vary considerably and may break down with excessive heat, such as prolonged cooking. Naturally occurring folate is not as easily absorbed in the body as folic acid.    Folic acid is important in the prevention of neural tube defects and for the normal development of a baby’s brain, spine, and skull. The effects of folic acid are most significant during the first few weeks of pregnancy.    All women of childbearing age should eat a diet rich in folate and begin taking a daily multivitamin containing 400 micrograms of folic acid at least 3 months before becoming pregnant. Women should continue this level of supplementation throughout their entire pregnancy.

Vitamin A is important for pregnant women living with HIV because it helps maintain a healthy immune system.    Pregnant women living with HIV are at risk of having preterm deliveries. Preterm delivery can increase the chance of vertical transmission of HIV. Research has suggested that taking vitamin A supplements during pregnancy may be associated with a reduced risk of preterm delivery and increased birth weight of babies born to women living with HIV. Health Canada recommends that pregnant women consume 700 micrograms of vitamin A per day.

Vitamin D is recommended during pregnancy as it helps the body absorb calcium, thereby assisting with the baby's bone development. Vitamin D also helps with the development of the baby’s immune system and the placenta, the part of the woman's body that feeds the baby during pregnancy. Research has shown that vitamin D could potentially reduce the risk of adverse pregnancy outcomes, vertical transmission of HIV, and child mortality.    Vitamin D is often called the sunshine vitamin as people can produce it in their bodies when exposed to the sun. In Saskatchewan, it is difficult to get enough exposure to sunshine for several months of the year. There are few foods that contain vitamin D in small amounts, including wild salmon, cod liver oil, sardines, and egg yolk. Vitamin D is also added to milk.    A vitamin D supplement is recommended for a pregnant woman living with HIV to be sure that both her and her baby are receiving enough vitamin D. Health Canada recommends that pregnant women take a supplement of 600 international units (IU)/15 micrograms per day.
Iron has been suggested to increase immune function and, therefore, some individuals living with HIV take iron supplements.

Women living with HIV should be encouraged to obtain needed nutrients from a balanced diet. The Canada Food Guide recommends: having plenty of vegetables and fruits, eating protein foods, choosing whole grain foods, and making water the drink of choice. Vitamin supplementation is encouraged when needed. Click the images to see examples of healthy food choices.
Vegetables and Fruits Examples include: pears, apples, berries, broccoli, peaches, cabbage, and leafy greens.
Whole Grain Products Examples include: quinoa, whole grain pasta, whole grain bread, oatmeal, and whole grain brown or wild rice.
Proteins  Examples include: beans, nuts, tofu, fish, shellfish, meat, eggs, milk, and cheese.

Researchers have investigated the advantages of multivitamin use in pregnant women living with HIV. Multivitamin supplements have been associated with improved CD4 lymphocyte counts and infant birth weights, as well as a reduced risk of growth restriction and severe prematurity. Multivitamins can also be helpful in regulating weight gain in pregnant women.

In addition to positive pregnancy outcomes, multivitamin supplements have been associated with health benefits for the mother, such as fewer HIV-related complications and a reduced chance of progressing to AIDS.     Consequently, it is recommended that multivitamin supplementation continue for three months postpartum in order to maintain a healthy nutritional status that can help combat infection.

Due to increased susceptibility to illness, implementing safe food handling practices and preventing foodborne illnesses (i.e., food poisoning) is very important for pregnant women living with HIV. Food poisoning is caused by food not being handled, cooked, or stored safely.

Having a weakened immune system puts pregnant women living with HIV at greater risk for food poisoning.  Food poisoning can  further weaken the immune system,  leading to weight  loss and the  development of new infections.
There are things that can be done to keep food safe. Click on buttons below for more information.
Frequently washing hands removes germs that can transfer to food and cause food poisoning.

If germs from raw meat touch ready-to-eat foods, food poisoning may result. Therefore, it is important to keep raw meat separate from ready-to-eat foods and to be sure that raw meat is not dripping onto food in the fridge. Areas exposed to raw meat should be washed with hot, soapy water before preparing other food.

Food poisoning may happen when a person eats food that is undercooked. It is important to cook food thoroughly until it reaches the right temperature. A pregnant woman living with HIV may wish to avoid foods that present a possible risk, such as raw or undercooked eggs and meat, unpasteurized milk, and raw fish.

Eating healthy helps women have healthy pregnancies. HIV and HIV medications may result in side effects that can affect a pregnant woman’s eating patterns.     Click on the buttons below for information about eating healthy while dealing with side effects.
Eat small meals often. Keep snacks handy. Choose foods with lots of nutrients like peanut butter, cheese, or yogurt.

Eat starchy foods like crackers and bread to help absorb gastric acid and reduce nausea.  Eat foods that are easy to digest such as toast, pasta, oatmeal, turkey, and pudding. Avoid spicy and greasy, high fat foods.
Eat foods such as bananas, toast, rice, and applesauce. Avoid high fat foods and lactose-containing foods. Drink lots of healthy fluids like water, sports drinks, and juices to replace lost fluids.

Eat foods such as pudding, yogurt, scrambled eggs, bananas, and applesauce. Avoid foods that are acidic or spicy, and those that have rough edges and textures. Add broths and gravies to foods to moisten them. Use a straw to drink liquids.

Despite advances in HIV treatments, weight loss can be a problem for individuals living with HIV.  Weight loss is a common side effect of HIV and is usually attributed to increased energy expenditure. Interestingly, although the reason is unknown, several studies  have reported that people with HIV tend to burn approximately 10% more  calories while resting than those who are uninfected.
It is expected that women should gain some weight during pregnancy, although there is caution about excessive weight gain.

For a woman with a healthy pre-pregnancy weight, the recommendation for pregnancy weight gain is between 11.5 and 16.0 kg (25 to 35 lb) but varies based on her body mass index (BMI).   The recommended BMI range for a woman is between 18.5 and 24.9. A pregnant woman with a BMI that is less than 18.5 should expect to gain 12.5 to 18 kg (28 to 40 lb), and a woman with a BMI of more than 25 to 29.9 should expect to gain 7 to 11.5 kg (15 to 25 lb). If a pregnant woman’s BMI is over 30, it is important for her to talk to a healthcare provider about how much weight she should gain.   In other words, women with a lower BMI should gain more weight, and women with a higher BMI should gain less with a physician’s guidance. Healthy weight gain during pregnancy is associated with a lower risk of complications during pregnancy and labour and a reduced risk of having a low birth weight infant. To calculate a pre-pregnancy BMI, visit the link on the next slide.

To calculate a BMI and get recommendations about weight gain in pregnancy, use Health Canada’s Pregnancy Weight Gain Calculator by clicking on the link below:     http://health.canada.ca/en/health-canada/services/food-nutrition/healthy-eating/prenatal-nutrition/pregnancy-weight-gain-calculator.html
